sub_topic: Calculation of Gibbs free energy change for a chemical reaction
message_1: What is the Gibbs free energy change for the reaction of hydrogen gas (H2) and chlorine gas (Cl2) to form hydrochloric acid (2HCl) at standard conditions (298 K and 1 atm)?
message_2:
To calculate the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) for the reaction of hydrogen gas (H2) and chlorine gas (Cl2) to form hydrochloric acid (2HCl) at standard conditions (298 K and 1 atm), we can use the following equation:

ΔG = ΔH - TΔS

where ΔH is the change in enthalpy, T is the temperature in Kelvin, and ΔS is the change in entropy.

First, we need to find the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) and standard entropy change (ΔS°) for the reaction. These values can be found in standard thermodynamic tables.

For the given reaction:
H2(g) + Cl2(g) → 2HCl(g)

The standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) and standard entropy change (ΔS°) are as follows:
ΔH°(H2) = 0 kJ/mol (since it is an element in its standard state)
ΔH°(Cl2) = 0 kJ/mol (since it is an element in its standard state)
ΔH°(HCl) = -92.3 kJ/mol

ΔS°(H2) = 130.7 J/mol·K
ΔS°(Cl2) = 223.1 J/mol·K
ΔS°(HCl) = 186.8 J/mol·K

Now, we can calculate the changes in enthalpy (ΔH) and entropy (ΔS) for the reaction:
ΔH = [2 * ΔH°(HCl)] - [ΔH°(H2) + ΔH°(Cl2)] = 2 * (-92.3) - (0 + 0) = -184.6 kJ/mol

ΔS = [2 * ΔS°(HCl)] - [ΔS°(H2) + ΔS°(Cl2)] = 2 * 186.8 - (130.7 + 223.1) = 373.6 - 353.8 = 19.8 J/mol·K

Now, we can calculate the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) at 298 K:
ΔG = ΔH - TΔS = -184.6 kJ/mol - (298 K * 19.8 J/mol·K / 1000 J/kJ) = -184.6 kJ/mol - 5.9 kJ/mol = -190.5 kJ/mol

So, the Gibbs free energy change for the reaction of hydrogen gas (H2) and chlorine gas (Cl2) to form hydrochloric acid (2HCl) at standard conditions (298 K and 1 atm) is -190.5 kJ/mol.
